awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Novel Smart Meters with Built-in Self-Test and Hardware Security
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is based on enhancing the reliability, longevity, security, and trustworthiness of the advanced metering infrastructure in smart grids. The integration of trustworthy information technology in the power grid will facilitate effective and efficient energy management in the presence of distributed generation with renewable sources. This team's technology, employing hardware-oriented security and trust, built-in self-test, and device authentication, can be applied to any industry that employs VLSI/FPGA chips and faces security risks. For example, this technology can be integrated into medical instrumentation in the health industry and dash-board chips in vehicles in the auto industry to make them more secure, reliable, and trustworthy.

This I-Corps project is based on earlier NSF funded research in the area of hardware-oriented security and testing of digital/integrated circuits. Its application in smart meters overcomes current meters problems by providing remote re-configurability to accommodate current and future technology advancements and additional security. While there are multiple smart meter manufacturers in the US, this project's technology has a strong focus on hardware re-programmability (leading to increased longevity and expandability), reliability, and security of the system. Also, current smart meters are not easily updated as technology advances. The proposed meters provide high security, based on special hardware based techniques, and incorporate built-in self-test circuitry. Hardware-oriented security is implemented using physical unclonable functions which provide authentication and trust to the programmable chip and also establish the authenticity of the smart meter. The meters can also detect the presence of hardware Trojans, which can be implanted by untrusted manufacturers and foundries abroad, to steal information or hamper the functionality of the device.

por.por_cntn:
The global smart meter market reached $ 20 billion in 2017, up from $ 4 billion in 2010. While there are multiple smart meter manufacturers in the US including Itron, General Electric, Emeter, Elster Group, etc., they lack a strong focus on hardware re-programmability (leading to increased longevity and expandability), reliability, and trustworthiness of the system. Current smart meters cannot be easily updated as technology advances. For example, in California, a large number of new smart meters became outdated and obsolete even as they waited for installation, and as a consequence, they were never installed incurring heavy losses to the owners.

                Our technology attempts to enhance current smart meters by providing  remote reconfigurability to accommodate technology advancements, and increased security and trust by providing an additional layer of hardware oriented security. The reconfigurability is provided by using FPGAs (Field Programmable Gate Arrays) instead of traditional micro-controllers.  FPGAs enable the execution of  several finite state machines at the same time and hence, unlike micro-controllers, can monitor  utilization in real-time instead of handling interrupts at regular time intervals.  The proposed smart meter design also includes an additional layer of security embedded in the FPGA chips. This type of security, commonly termed as hardware-oriented security, is implemented by using Physical Unclonable Functions (PUFs), which provide authentication and trust to the FPGA and also ensures communication authentication between the smart meter and the utility company. Our design also includes Built-in Self-Test (BIST), which regularly checks the internal circuitry for faults and hardware failures in order to notify the utility companies of  potential failures.  The BIST circuitry is also capable of by-passing  faults by  re-routing the circuitry, thus making the system fault tolerant.

                The main aim of our I-Corps project was to explore market need for our proposed technology. For this purpose, the team  interviewed more than 110 company representatives from well known power  utilities and smart meter manufacturers. At the end of our customer discovery process, it was found that there indeed was a great need for our proposed product. However, it was also felt that we were competing against well established smart meter manufacturers with deep pockets, and it  would  not be easy for a new start-up like ours to compete with them. Hence, we decided to go back to our research lab and do some more development work and research with the aim of designing a smart chip which could be incorporated inside existing smart meters to enhance their capabilities. Our next step would be to try for a pilot project with one of the power utilities/smart meter manufacturers we have interviewed.
